newsitem.title: ITALY: Italian, Canadian police smash drugs ring.
newsitem.headline: Italian, Canadian police smash drugs ring.

text.p: Italian police said on Saturday they had smashed a major drugs smuggling ring, arresting six people and seizing 50 kg (100 lb) of heroin with a street value estimated at 40 billion lire ($25 million).

The police said they had arrested three Iranians, two of whom lived in Canada, and three Poles early on Saturday in Rome in an operation dubbed "Overtrick" and conducted by an anti-Mafia unit in conjunction with Canadian police.
The drugs were found hidden in the interior linings of several cars, police said.
"We were able to pull this off thanks to undercover agents who were able to infiltrate the gang and win the confidence of the smugglers," Rome police chief Rodolfo Ronconi told a news conference.
"To do this, they had to show the smugglers 14 billion lire ($9.2 million) in cash, kept in two suitcases," said Ronconi, adding that the undercover agents were Canadian.
He said the crime group bought the heroin in Turkey and smuggled it through former Yugoslavia, stopping sometimes in Italian territory.
Canadian police tracking the group asked their Italian counterparts for help after learning of the gang's stopovers in Italy, Ronconi said. ($1=1,527 lire)
